thread.title: Trump’s electronics ban leaves frequent fliers enraged
thread.title_full: Trump’s electronics ban leaves frequent fliers enraged | New York Post

author: Alex Taylor
title: Trump’s electronics ban leaves frequent fliers enraged
text:
President Trump’s ban on large carry-on electronics between 10 foreign cities and the United States will be a first-class headache for New Yorkers who frequently fly those routes, travelers said Tuesday.
“My tablet is my whole office,” complained Muhammad Farooq, 50, a New York-based engineer who just last week flew to Dubai, one of the transit hubs covered by the order. “Now I’m supposed to leave work behind?”
The ban bars passengers coming to the US from 10 airports in the Middle East and Africa from bringing electronic devices that are larger than a cellphone — including laptops, tablets and cameras — in their carry-on luggage.

Families were left wondering what they’ll do to entertain their tots during long flights.
“It’s going to be tough with the kids,” said father-of-two Shankar, who was picking up his in-laws from JFK Airport and declined to give his last name. “We’re definitely going to need to reconsider where and how we travel, what airports we use.”
Asif Muhammed, 35, a medical student who lives in New York and travels to Turkey occasionally, said he heard about the ban in the middle his flight from Dubai. “It’s crazy,” he said. “Just wow.”
The Global Business Travel Association said 49 percent of business travelers get work done on their devices while in the air.
“Not allowing them to bring their devices on the plane cuts productivity, taking away time that they can be getting business done,” the organization said in a statement.
“Many business travelers also prefer to keep their devices close for security purposes because they may contain sensitive company information. If it is in the best interest of security, business travelers are willing to comply with these types of measures. ”
The Department of Homeland Security said Tuesday the ban was the result of intelligence indicating “that terrorist groups continue to target commercial aviation and are aggressively pursuing innovative methods to undertake their attacks.”
An official told BuzzFeed the move was made in response to more recent threats from militants saying they wanted to smuggle explosives into computers.
